title: MPD Surface Back Pressure Adjustment
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are using MPD at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD. Current mud weight is {{currentSection.mudWeight.current}} ppg with pore pressure at {{scenario.porePressure}} ppg EMW. The driller reports ECD drops {{scenario.ecdDrop}} ppg when pumps are shut off for a connection. What surface back pressure (SBP) should be applied during the connection to maintain constant BHP?

ecdDrop.description: ppg equivalent ECD reduction when pumps off

steps: Identify the ECD drop when pumps stop
Convert this drop to pressure at TD
Apply this pressure at surface to maintain constant BHP

feedback.correct: Correct. SBP = {{answer}} psi. This compensates for the {{scenario.ecdDrop}} ppg ECD loss when circulation stops, maintaining constant bottom hole pressure.
feedback.incorrect: SBP = ECD Drop × 0.052 × TVD. With {{scenario.ecdDrop}} ppg drop at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} ft, SBP = {{answer}} psi.
feedback.hint: Think of it this way: when you stop pumping, you lose ECD. Surface back pressure replaces what ECD was providing.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, MPD is required below the intermediate casing due to tight mud weight windows. Proper SBP management prevents swab kicks during connections.
advancedNote: L4 supervisors must understand that SBP has limits - check that the total equivalent pressure (MW + SBP equivalent) doesn't exceed formation fracture gradient.
